Dear @alexis and @IslandHunting, the whole idea of Dai, dating back to about 2015, is that Dai is always overcollateralized. In a world of dubious fiat currencies and volatile crypto currencies, users need money they can trust. The split second we "print just a few dai to get the peg right ", the whole picture changes. Dai will suddenly become just another fiat currency with the associated problems that brings. I love to hear about all sorts of ideas - but pretty please - don’t seriously bring up printing unbacked Dai.

content.content: I don’t care what the idea of Dai was in 2015. I care about Dai actually working and being useful in July 2020. I am currently short a large amount of Dai via a vault loan, and Dai trading up to $1.03 is a problem for me if the price continues to blow out. I have real skin in this game. Theoretical considerations on what Dai should be based on what we knew in 2015 are not very relevant in today’s environment of liquidity farming and negative real interest rates on Ethereum. We need effective solutions to restore the peg. Six months of trying to onboard more collateral hasn’t done it, and certainly won’t do it now. A lot of people don’t want to borrow Dai until Dai has proven that it can maintain the $1 peg. That’s the bottom line here. Personally, I would prefer printing Dai to buy ETH over printing Dai to buy USDC. I’d prefer printing MKR for borrowers to subsidize Dai creation over both of those, but it may be too late for that to be effective.
